source.33219e73:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
%matplotlib inline
source.97c55e7e:
sns.barplot(x="Rating", y="Unit price",  data=data[180:200])
plt.title("Rating vs Unit Price",fontsize=15)
plt.xlabel("Rating")
plt.ylabel("Unit Price")
plt.show()
source.4100e975:
sns.scatterplot(x="Rating", y="Unit price", hue="Gender", data=data)
plt.title("Rating vs Unit Price",fontsize=15)
plt.xlabel("Rating")
plt.ylabel("Unit Price")
plt.show()
source.65ea16c1:
sns.regplot(x="Rating", y="cogs", data=data)
plt.title("Rating vs Cogs",fontsize=15)
plt.xlabel("Rating")
plt.ylabel("cogs")
plt.show()
source.00176a95:
sns.lmplot(x="Rating", y="Unit price", hue="Gender", data=data)
plt.title("Rating vs Unit Price",fontsize=15)
plt.xlabel("Rating")
plt.ylabel("Unit Price")
plt.show()
source.8ee9a33f:
sns.swarmplot(y="Rating", x="Gender", data=data)
plt.title("Rating vs Gender",fontsize=15)
plt.xlabel("Rating")
plt.ylabel("Gender")
plt.show()
source.1d0f8ccb:
# **Relationship**
There are many different chart types that you can use to understand relationships between variables in your data.
source.f661303a:
# **Distribution**

We visualize distributions to show the possible values that we can expect to see in a variable, along with how likely they are.
source.68fe373e:
# **Trends** 
1. A trend is defined as a pattern of change.
1. **sns.lineplot** - Line charts are best to show trends over a period of time, and multiple lines can be used to show trends in more than one group.
source.23621f78:
1. **sns.distplot** - **Histograms** show the distribution of a single numerical variable.
1. **sns.kdeplot** - **KDE plots (or 2D KDE plots)** show an estimated, smooth distribution of a single numerical variable (or two numerical variables).
1. **sns.jointplot** - This command is useful for simultaneously displaying a 2D KDE plot with the corresponding KDE plots for each individual variable.
source.78bc9f17:
1. **sns.barplot** - **Bar charts** are useful for comparing quantities corresponding to different groups.
1. **sns.heatmap** - **Heatmaps** can be used to find color-coded patterns in tables of numbers.
1. **sns.scatterplot** - **Scatter plots** show the relationship between two continuous variables; if color-coded, we can also show the relationship with a third categorical variable.
1. **sns.regplot** - Including a regression line in the **scatter plot** makes it easier to see any linear relationship between two variables.
1. **sns.lmplot** - This command is useful for **drawing multiple regression lines**, if the scatter plot contains multiple, color-coded groups.
1. **sns.swarmplot** - **Categorical scatter plots** show the relationship between a continuous variable and a categorical variable.
